anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal in this respect has mainly taken into account the facts brought to light by the order made in appeal arising out of the refusal of the Income Tax authorities to register Kohinoor Mills.

holdings.text: The Income Tax Officer was satisfied in the course of assessment proceedings under the Act that the assessee concealed particulars of income or furnished inaccurate particulars, as evidenced by the assessment orders holding Kohinoor Mills to be the proprietary concern of the assessee and directing issuance of notice under section 271(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we find that the Income Tax Officer while making the assessment orders for the assessment years in question held that Kohinoor Mills had been wrongly shown to be a partnership firm and that the other alleged partners were simply name lenders for the assessee. It was further held that Kohinoor Mills was the Proprietary concern of the assessee and the income from that concern should be considered to be the income of the assessee. Notice was ordered to be issued for proposed penalty under section 271 1  c  of the Act to the assessee in regard to the concealment of and furnishing inaccurate particulars of income from Kohinoor Mills.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applied facts of assessment orders where ITO held business proprietary and directed penalty notice to find satisfaction during proceedings.

holdings.text: Issuance of notices subsequent to assessment orders does not negate the Income Tax Officer's satisfaction during the assessment proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: Notices, it would appear, were thereafter issued by the Income Tax Officer to the assessee. The fact that notices were issued subsequent to the making of the assessment orders would not, in our opinion, show that there was no satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer during the assessment proceedings that the assessee had concealed the particulars of his income or had furnished incorrect particulars of such income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Satisfaction must precede notice; timing of notice does not determine when satisfaction occurred.

holdings.text: Satisfaction precedes the issue of notice, and it is sufficient if the Income Tax Officer is satisfied during proceedings under the Act even if notice is issued subsequently.

anchor.surface_text: What is contemplated by clause  1  of section 271 is that the Income Tax Officer or the Appellate Assistant Commissioner should have been satisfied in the course of proceedings under the Act regarding matters mentioned in the clauses of that sub- section. It is not, however, essential that notice to the person proceeded against should have also been issued during the course of the assessment proceedings. Satisfaction in the very nature of things precedes the issue of notice and it would not be correct to equate the satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer or Appellate Assistant Commissioner with the actual issue of notice.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual interpretation of s271(1)(c); satisfaction is prerequisite to notice, not contemporaneous with issuance.

holdings.text: Proceedings for penalty under s271(1) are initiated by ITO even if referred to IAC under s274(2) when minimum penalty exceeds Rs.1000.

anchor.surface_text: We are also not impressed by the argument advanced on behalf of the appellant that the proceedings for the imposition of penalty were initiated not by the Income Tax Officer but by the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner when the matter had been referred to him under section 274 2  of the Act. The proceedings for the imposition of penalty in terms of sub- section  1  of section 271 have necessarily to be initiated either by the Income Tax Officer or by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Statutory procedure under s274(2) supplements initiation by ITO; referral follows initiation.

holdings.text: No preliminary enquiry or prior notice to assessee required before ITO forms satisfaction and directs penalty notice under s271(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: There is also no force in the submission made on behalf of the appellant that the Income Tax Officer before feeling satisfied regarding the necessity of initiating proceedings for imposition of penalty and before issuing consequential notice should have issued another notice to the assessee and held a preliminary enquiry regarding the necessity of initiating proceedings. Such a course, in our opinion, would result in mere duplication of the procedure without any advantage to the parties.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Analogy to s34(1922) via Judicial Committee; avoids duplication; prima facie satisfaction before hearing under s274.

holdings.text: There was relevant material and evidence before the Tribunal to hold deliberate concealment or furnishing inaccurate particulars under s271(1)(c).

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be said that there was no relevant material or evidence before the Tribunal to hold that the assessee had deliberately concealed the particulars of his income or had deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of such income.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepted Tribunal's findings from registration appeal on dummy partners, assessee control, and scheme to disguise profits as evidence of deliberate concealment.

holdings.text: Penalty leviable under s271(1)(c) where positive material shows deliberate device for concealment, beyond mere falsity of assessee's explanation; Anwar Ali distinguished.

anchor.surface_text: In this respect we find that in the present case the inference that the assessee had consciously concealed the particulars of his income or had deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars is based not merely upon the falsity of the explanation given by the assessee. On the contrary, it is made amply clear by the order of the Tribunal that there was positive material to indicate that the business of Kohinoor Mills belonged to the assessee and the whole scheme was to disguise the profits of the assessee as those of a firm of four partners. The present is not a case of inference from mere falsity of explanation given by the assessee but a case wherein there are definite findings that a device had been deliberately created by the assessee for the purpose of concealing his income. The assessee as such can derive no assistance from Anwar Alis case.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguished Anwar Ali as here positive evidence of scheme, not just false explanation; burden met by entirety of circumstances.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras and Another S. V. Angidi Chettiar 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras and Another S. V. Angidi Chettiar 1 . Shah J speaking for the Court while dealing with section 28 of the Indian Income Tax Act, 1922 observed  1  1962 441.T.R.739. The power to impose penalty under section 28 depends upon the satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer in the companyrse of proceedings under the Act it cannot be exercised if he is number satisfied about the existence of companyditions specified in clauses  a ,  b  or  c  before the proceedings are companycluded.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. S.V. Angidi Chettiar
precedents.cited_proposition: Satisfaction of Income Tax Officer in the course of proceedings under the Act is prerequisite for penalty jurisdiction under section 28 of 1922 Act, but penalty proceedings need not commence before assessment completion
precedents.cited_holding: The power to impose penalty under section 28 depends upon the satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer in the course of proceedings under the Act it cannot be exercised if he is number satisfied about the existence of companyditions specified in clauses  a ,  b  or  c  before the proceedings are companycluded. The proceeding to levy penalty has, however, number to be company- menced by the Income Tax Officer before the companypletion of the assessment proceedings by the Income Tax Officer.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. M s. Mahaliram Ramjidas 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. M s. Mahaliram Ramjidas 1  in the following words Therefore a companystruction of section 34 which requires a quasi-judicial enquiry to be held before the powers under the section can be operated would result in mere duplication of procedure and in two enquiries of the same kind, into the same matter, companyducted by the same official, and without any advantage to the parties.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Bengal v. Messrs. Mahaliram Ramjidas
precedents.cited_proposition: No quasi-judicial enquiry or opportunity of hearing required before Income Tax Officer decides to initiate proceedings under section 34 of 1922 Act
precedents.cited_holding: Therefore a companystruction of section 34 which requires a quasi-judicial enquiry to be held before the powers under the section can be operated would result in mere duplication of procedure and in two enquiries of the same kind, into the same matter, companyducted by the same official, and without any advantage to the parties. A companystruction so unreasonable and unpractical ought number to be preferred when another companystruction is open.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal I v. Anwar Ali 1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal I v. Anwar Ali 1  wherein the relevant head-note which is based upon the observations in the body of the judgment, reads as under Proceedings under section 28 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 are penal in character. The gist of the offence under section 2 8  1   c  is that the assessee has companycealed the particulars of his income or deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of such income

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, West Bengal v. Anwar Ali
precedents.cited_proposition: Penalty under section 28(1)(c) of 1922 Act requires department to prove concealment or inaccurate particulars; mere falsity of assessee's explanation insufficient without entirety of circumstances pointing to conscious concealment
precedents.cited_holding: Proceedings under section 28 of the Income Tax Act, 1922 are penal in character. The gist of the offence under section 2 8  1   c  is that the assessee has companycealed the particulars of his income or deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of such income and the burden is on the department to establish that the receipt of the amount in dispute companystitutes income of the assessee.

precedents.citation: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Khoday Eswarsa and Sons  1

anchor.surface_text: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Khoday Eswarsa and Sons  1  that penalty cannot be levied solely on the basis of the reasons given in the original order of assessment. It is, however, number necessary to go into this aspect of the matter because the penalty in the present case has number been levied solely on the basis of the reasons given in the original order of assessment.

precedents.case_name: Commissioner of Income Tax, Madras v. Khoday Eswara and Sons
precedents.cited_proposition: Penalty cannot be levied solely on the basis of reasons given in the original assessment order

anchor.surface_text: er while making the assessment orders for the assessment years in question held that Kohinoor Mills had been wrongly shown to be a partnership firm an

edges.explanation: Holding states ITO was satisfied in course of assessment proceedings under the Act, directly addressing whether penalty proceedings properly commenced in course of proceedings under the Act.

anchor.surface_text: In the present case, we find that the Income Tax Officer while making the assessment orders for the assessment years in question held that Kohinoor Mills had been wrongly shown to be a partnership firm and that the other alleged partners were simply name lenders for the assessee. It was further held that Kohinoor Mills was the Proprietary concern of the assessee and the income from that concern should be considered to be the income of the assessee. Notice was ordered to be issued for proposed penalty under section 271 1  c  of the Act to the assessee in regard to the concealment of and furnishing inaccurate particulars of income from Kohinoor Mills.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.
regard to the companycealment of and furnishing inaccurate particulars of income from Kohinoor Mills. Notices, it would appear, were thereafter issued

edges.explanation: Holding clarifies that subsequent notices do not negate satisfaction during assessment proceedings, addressing the timing aspect of proper commencement.

anchor.surface_text: Notices, it would appear, were thereafter issued by the Income Tax Officer to the assessee. The fact that notices were issued subsequent to the making of the assessment orders would not, in our opinion, show that there was no satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer during the assessment proceedings that the assessee had concealed the particulars of his income or had furnished incorrect particulars of such income.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.

anchor.surface_text: ect particulars of such income. What is companytemplated by clause  1  of section 271 is that the Income Tax Officer or the Appellate Assistant Commis

edges.explanation: Holding establishes that satisfaction during proceedings under the Act is sufficient even if notice issued subsequently, directly addressing proper commencement of penalty proceedings.

anchor.surface_text: What is contemplated by clause  1  of section 271 is that the Income Tax Officer or the Appellate Assistant Commissioner should have been satisfied in the course of proceedings under the Act regarding matters mentioned in the clauses of that sub- section. It is not, however, essential that notice to the person proceeded against should have also been issued during the course of the assessment proceedings. Satisfaction in the very nature of things precedes the issue of notice and it would not be correct to equate the satisfaction of the Income Tax Officer or Appellate Assistant Commissioner with the actual issue of notice.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.

edges.explanation: h3 follows Angidi Chettiar p1 on sufficiency of satisfaction before conclusion of proceedings

anchor.surface_text: Income Tax Officer before feeling satisfied regarding the necessity of initiating proceedings for imposition of penalty and before issuing companysequ

edges.explanation: Holding confirms penalty proceedings under s271(1) initiated by ITO even if referred to IAC, addressing whether proceedings properly commenced.

anchor.surface_text: We are also not impressed by the argument advanced on behalf of the appellant that the proceedings for the imposition of penalty were initiated not by the Income Tax Officer but by the Inspecting Assistant Commissioner when the matter had been referred to him under section 274 2  of the Act. The proceedings for the imposition of penalty in terms of sub- section  1  of section 271 have necessarily to be initiated either by the Income Tax Officer or by the Appellate Assistant Commissioner.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.
er companystruction is open. Accordingly, their Lordships are of opinion that the Income Tax Officer is number required by the section to companyvene

edges.explanation: Absence of need for prior notice before satisfaction in h5 supports the validity of ITO's satisfaction during assessment in h1.

anchor.surface_text: er companystruction is open. Accordingly, their Lordships are of opinion that the Income Tax Officer is number required by the section to companyvene

edges.explanation: Holding states no prior notice or enquiry required before ITO satisfaction for penalty notice, addressing requirements for proper commencement.

anchor.surface_text: There is also no force in the submission made on behalf of the appellant that the Income Tax Officer before feeling satisfied regarding the necessity of initiating proceedings for imposition of penalty and before issuing consequential notice should have issued another notice to the assessee and held a preliminary enquiry regarding the necessity of initiating proceedings. Such a course, in our opinion, would result in mere duplication of the procedure without any advantage to the parties.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.

edges.explanation: h6 on relevant material supports h7 on leviability of penalty
h6 addresses i2 on material before Tribunal for concealment

anchor.surface_text: It cannot therefore be said that there was no relevant material or evidence before the Tribunal to hold that the assessee had deliberately concealed the particulars of his income or had deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars of such income.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.

edges.explanation: h7 addresses i2 on leviability based on deliberate concealment material

anchor.surface_text: In this respect we find that in the present case the inference that the assessee had consciously concealed the particulars of his income or had deliberately furnished inaccurate particulars is based not merely upon the falsity of the explanation given by the assessee. On the contrary, it is made amply clear by the order of the Tribunal that there was positive material to indicate that the business of Kohinoor Mills belonged to the assessee and the whole scheme was to disguise the profits of the assessee as those of a firm of four partners. The present is not a case of inference from mere falsity of explanation given by the assessee but a case wherein there are definite findings that a device had been deliberately created by the assessee for the purpose of concealing his income. The assessee as such can derive no assistance from Anwar Alis case.
The above submissions have been companytroverted by Mr. Karkhanis on behalf of the department and, in our opinion, are without merit.

edges.explanation: h7 distinguishes Anwar Ali p3 on proof required for penalty
i1 directly addresses the c3 requirement for commencement in course of proceedings
Resolving i1 requires application of c3 concept
